1. Frankenstein by Mary Shelley - This novel is considered to be one of the most iconic works of Gothic literature. It tells the story of a mad scientist who creates a monster and the dark consequences that follow.

2. The Castle of Otranto by Horace Walpole - This is the first novel ever written in the Gothic genre. It's a story of mystery and terror that takes place in an ancient Italian castle.

3. Dracula by Bram Stoker - This is a classic tale of horror and suspense that tells the story of Count Dracula, a vampire who preys on innocent victims.

4. The Picture of Dorian Gray by Oscar Wilde - This novel explores the dark side of human nature through the story of a young man who sells his soul to the devil in exchange for eternal youth and beauty.

5. The Bride of Frankenstein (film) - This movie is a classic of the horror genre and is considered one of the best sequels ever made. It tells the story of Dr. Frankenstein's second creation, the Bride of Frankenstein.

What makes these works iconic is their use of supernatural and macabre elements such as ghosts, supernatural creatures, and haunted houses. They also explore themes of terror, madness, and the darker aspects of humanity. Gothic works often feature dark and mysterious settings, such as old castles or dark forests, which add to the sense of horror and dread. The Gothic genre has been popular for centuries and continues to inspire artists and writers to this day.
